definition: Tan Sitong (1865-1898), Qing writer and politician, one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子 of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
variant of 談|谈[tan2]
surname Tan
succession (to a title)/to inherit/continuing (a tradition)/posterity

(used in given names)/variant of 同[tong2]
see 衚衕|胡同[hu2 tong4]

sentences.english: In China's modern history, Tan Sitong's heroic death may be the most exciting event.
sentences.chinese: 谭嗣同的慷慨成仁是中国近代史上最激动人心的华章。

sentences.english: Early years, such as the creation of the Southern Society and Tan.
sentences.chinese: 早年与谭嗣同等创立南学会。

sentences.english: Tan Hi "to ride the unruly text, speaking slightly Overlord statecraft."
sentences.chinese: 谭嗣同喜“为驰骋不羁之文，讲霸王经世之略”。

sentences.english: Tan Sitong was an outstanding social reformer at the end of the Qing Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 谭嗣同是清末杰出的社会改革家。

definition: the Six Gentlemen Martyrs of the failed reform movement of 1898, executed in its aftermath, namely: Tan Sitong 譚嗣同|谭嗣同[Tan2 Si4 tong2], Lin Xu 林旭[Lin2 Xu4], Yang Shenxiu 楊深秀|杨深秀[Yang2 Shen1 xiu4], Liu Guangdi 劉光第|刘光第[Liu2 Guang1 di4], Kang Guangren 康廣仁|康广仁[Kang1 Guang3 ren2] and Yang Rui 楊銳|杨锐[Yang2 Rui4]
Yang Shenxiu (1849-1898), one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子[Wu4 xu1 Liu4 jun1 zi5] of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
Liu Guangdi (1859-1898), one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子[Wu4 xu1 Liu4 jun1 zi5] of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
Kang Guangren (1867-1898), younger brother of Kang Youwei 康有為|康有为[Kang1 You3 wei2] and one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子 of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
Chen Tianhua (1875-1905), anti-Qing revolutionary from Hunan, drowned himself in Japan in 1905
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Qiu Jin (1875-1907), famous female martyr of the anti-Qing revolution, the subject of several books and films
Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
the reformist faction
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
coup by Dowager Empress Cixi 慈禧太后[Ci2 xi3 tai4 hou4] ending the 1898 attempt to reform the Qing dynasty
Hundred Days Reform (1898), failed attempt to reform the Qing dynasty
Hundred Days Reform (1898), failed attempt to reform the Qing dynasty
Li Dazhao (1889-1927), early Chinese Marxist and founding member of the communist party
Zhang Zhidong (1837-1909), prominent politician in late Qing
Huang Xing (1874-1916), revolutionary politician, close collaborator of Sun Yat-sen, prominent in the 1911 Xinhai Revolution 辛亥革命[Xin1 hai4 Ge2 ming4], murdered in Shanghai in 1916
